The Plotter Widget is a PyQt5-based graphical interface integrated into QGIS that enables users to plot calculated points like cut points, offset points, and extended points along a selected line feature. üéØ This tool is especially valuable for precision mapping and SVAMITVA survey workflows requiring accurate line-based geometry operations.
This tool allows you to easily move polygon vertices or adjust side lengths directly on your QGIS map using a guided, click-based process. It's designed for simplicity, precision, and clarity.
The Tool Panel is a floating window inside QGIS that gives access to multiple custom tools, useful for working with land parcels, base lines, and plotting boundaries. It includes buttons for:

Gruhanaksha is a specialized QGIS plugin developed to support the preparation, validation, and finalization of geospatial deliverables under the SVAMITVA (Survey of Villages and Mapping with Improvised Technology in Village Areas) scheme. It streamlines the workflows for SVAMITVA Team by offering tools for: Generating map outputs as per SVAMITVA standards Integrating field inputs and updated survey data Producing deliverables such as property cards, ownership maps, and attribute reports
Get started by Downloading the Plugin from Gruhanaksha web or from here üåµ Prerequisites Gruhanaksha requires QGIS version 3.26 or newer for compatibility and functionality.
Click on Download Loading... Old Releases No old releases available. All Releases button Locate the plugin file you want to install in your PC(Laptop). The plugin file is usually in ZIP file format
Launch the QGIS(>2.26) application on your computer. In the QGIS menu, go to "Plugins" Click on "Manage and Install Plugins". In the Plugin Manager window, go to the "Installed" tab.

Click on the "Install from ZIP" button. Browse your computer to select the Gruhanaksha plugin ZIP file you want to install. Click "Install Plugin." Once installed, you may need to enable the plugin by checking the box next to its name. Close the Plugin Manager. success Yeah, you did it! üöÄ You're now armed with incredible new tools at your fingertips. Let the adventure begin!

The Baseline Tool in QGIS allows users to create baseline geometries (üìè lines or üü† circles) based on a user-defined distance. This tool helps in digitizing and mapping linear and circular features with precision.

Supports line üìè and circle üü† geometries. Allows users to enter a specific distance value üî¢ for precise placement. Provides snapping üß≤ to existing features for accurate alignment. Includes a preview mode üëÄ before finalizing the geometry. Supports multiple measurement units: üìê Meters üîó Metric Links üîó Guntur's Links
Click on the Baseline Tool üß≠ in the QGIS toolbar. The tool will be activated, and the mouse cursor will change accordingly.
üñ±Ô∏è Left-click on the map to select the starting point for the baseline. The tool will highlight the chosen location with a green marker üü¢.

A dialog box will appear prompting you to enter the distance üî¢. Select the desired unit of measurement üìè. Choose the geometry type: üìè Line: A straight segment of the specified distance. üü† Circle: A circular feature with the given radius. Click OK ‚úÖ to confirm.

Move the cursor to see a preview üëÅÔ∏è of the feature. The tool will display: ‚ûñ A dashed line for line geometry. üåÄ A dashed circle for circular geometry. üñ±Ô∏è Right-click to cancel ‚ùå if needed.
üñ±Ô∏è Left-click again to confirm the geometry. The feature will be added to the Baseline layer üóÇÔ∏è. The tool will automatically reset üîÑ for a new operation.

üß≤ Snapping Support: The tool will snap to existing features based on QGIS's snapping settings. üßÆ Length Attribute: Each feature stores its measured distance in the attribute table. ‚Ü©Ô∏è Undo Support: If needed, remove the last created feature and retry.
Ensure that the entered distance is greater than 0. Check that the distance value is within valid range (0.01 - 10,000 meters).
Verify that snapping is enabled üß≤ in QGIS settings. Adjust snapping tolerance for better results.
Ensure that the Baseline layer is editable ‚úçÔ∏è. If an error occurs, check the QGIS message bar ‚ÑπÔ∏è for details.

The Baseline Tool üß≠ is a powerful QGIS extension for efficiently creating linear and circular baseline features. By allowing precise distance input and real-time preview, this tool enhances the digitization workflow üöÄ.

The Plotter Widget is a PyQt5-based graphical interface integrated into QGIS that enables users to plot calculated points like cut points, offset points, and extended points along a selected line feature. üéØ This tool is especially valuable for precision mapping and SVAMITVA survey workflows requiring accurate line-based geometry operations.

üìè Unit Conversion Meters Metric Links (1 = 0.2 meters) Gunter‚Äôs Links (1 = 0.201168 meters) üìå Base Point Selection Start Point End Point üìê Point Types Cut Point: At a given length along the line. Offset Point: Perpendicular to the line at a given distance. Extended Point: When the length exceeds the original line. üóÇÔ∏è Memory Layer Integration Outputs are saved as a new memory layer. Works with both single-part and multi-part lines. üé® Categorized Symbology Green: Start Point Red: End Point Orange: Cut Point Blue: Offset Point Purple: Extended Point üõ°Ô∏è Robust Error Handling Clear messages guide users to correct inputs.
Open QGIS. From the plugin menu or the custom GUI, open Plotter Widget.
Activate a line layer from the Layers panel. Select exactly one line feature. ‚ÑπÔ∏è Supports both single and multi-part geometries.
Choose from: Meters Metric Links Gunter‚Äôs Links
Select whether to start from the: Start Point End Point
Enter the distance for the cut point. Negative value ‚Üí Extends the line backward.
Enter perpendicular offset distance. Positive ‚Üí Right of line. Negative ‚Üí Left of line.
Click Plot ‚ñ∂Ô∏è The tool generates: ‚úÖ Cut Point üîµ Offset Point üü£ Extended Point (if applicable) They are added to a new memory layer: "Plotted Points".
Color Point Type üü¢ Green Start Point üî¥ Red End Point üü† Orange Cut Point üîµ Blue Offset Point üü£ Purple Extended Point You can rerun the widget with new values as needed.

‚ùó Error Message üí° Cause ‚úÖ Solution "Please select a layer." No layer selected Select a line layer in QGIS. "Selected layer is not a line layer." Wrong geometry type Use a valid line geometry layer. "Select exactly one line feature." 0 or multiple features selected Select one valid line feature. "Feature has no geometry." Geometry is missing Choose a feature with valid lines. "Cut point calculation failed." Input error or geometry problem Check values and retry.

‚úîÔ∏è Always validate your selected feature before plotting. üìè Use correct units based on your CRS and survey standards. üß© Understand the behavior with multi-part lines. üíæ Save the memory layer if needed for further analysis.

üó∫Ô∏è Scenario: You want to place a cut point 50m from the start of a road, then offset it 10m right for boundary marking. Input Value Units Meters Base Point Start Cut Length 50 Offset Length 10 üßÆ Result: A cut point at 50m An offset point 10m to the right Layer: "Plotted Points"

‚ûñ Use negative cut lengths to extend backwards. üßº The layer is always reset to prevent duplicates. üîÅ Reuse for multiple segments ‚Äì each run updates the points cleanly. üìå The Plotter Widget empowers SVAMITVA workflows and survey operations with high precision and ease. Whether you're mapping cadastral plots or engineering offsets, this tool ensures spatial accuracy every step of the way. üó∫Ô∏èüìç

The Master Panel is a user-friendly form in QGIS designed to help you easily enter and manage administrative details such as: District Mandal Name (in English) Panchayat Name Grama Panchayat Code Village (LGD) Code This panel is useful for surveyors, map editors, or government staff who regularly work with village-level maps and need to maintain consistency across maps, reports, and templates.

You can open the Master Panel from within QGIS toolbar. Right Click on Toolbar ‚ñ∂ Enable Gruhanaksha Toolbar ‚ñ∂ Click on the Master Panel icon in the Toolbar From Plugin Menu: Plugins ‚ñ∂ Gruhanaksha ‚ñ∂ Master Data Once opened, you will see a simple form with labeled fields and two buttons at the bottom: Clear and Update.

Field What to Enter Choose Your District Select your district from the dropdown list. Each entry is shown in English followed by the Telugu name in brackets. Mandal Name (English) Type the mandal name using English letters. For example: Anandapuram. Panchayat Name Type the name of the panchayat (village council). Grama Panchayat Code Enter the official code assigned to the panchayat. Village (LGD) Code Enter the LGD (Local Government Directory) village code.

Click the dropdown at the top labeled ‚ÄúChoose Your District‚Äù. Scroll and select your district. Each item is displayed in the format: District Name (‡∞§‡±Ü‡∞≤‡±Å‡∞ó‡±Å ‡∞™‡±á‡∞∞‡±Å), e.g., Srikakulam (‡∞∂‡±ç‡∞∞‡±Ä‡∞ï‡∞æ‡∞ï‡±Å‡∞≥‡∞Ç).

Fill out the other fields: Enter the Mandal Name using English letters. Provide the Panchayat Name, Grama Panchayat Code, and Village Code carefully. There is no need to worry about uppercase/lowercase‚Äîentries are automatically converted to Proper Case (e.g., rajam ‚Üí Rajam).

After filling in all the details, click the Update button at the bottom. A pop-up message will confirm: "Data has been successfully updated." üóÇÔ∏è Your data is now saved and can be reused by other QGIS tools, map layouts, or custom forms.
Click the Clear button to reset all fields. This is useful if you want to enter new data for a different area or correct mistakes.

‚úÖ Easy-to-use form with clear labels ‚úÖ Districts listed in both English and Telugu ‚úÖ Automatically remembers your last-used entries ‚úÖ Makes sure your inputs are consistently formatted ‚úÖ Saves time during repetitive map and report generation

You are preparing a land parcel map for the Kotturu Mandal in Srikakulam District. Open the Master Panel ‚Üí Select Srikakulam (‡∞∂‡±ç‡∞∞‡±Ä‡∞ï‡∞æ‡∞ï‡±Å‡∞≥‡∞Ç) ‚Üí Enter Kotturu, Pathapatnam, GP Code 1056, Village Code 112233. Click Update. Now, any map template or labeling script in QGIS can access these values automatically.

Make sure you click the Update button after filling in or changing any field. Otherwise, your data won‚Äôt be saved. When you reopen the Master Panel later, your previous entries will load automatically for quick editing. Only one set of values can be stored at a time. Updating will overwrite previous values.
This tool allows you to easily move polygon vertices or adjust side lengths directly on your QGIS map using a guided, click-based process. It's designed for simplicity, precision, and clarity.
You must be editing a polygon layer. Ensure the layer is in editing mode (pencil icon activated).

Click a polygon on the map. Click one of its vertices. Choose an operation from the dialog: Move a vertex by a given distance. Set the length of one side of the polygon. Click a direction on the map to apply your change. Confirm or cancel the operation.

From your plugin panel or button (depending on how it's integrated), click to activate the Unified Polygon Edit Tool. A message will appear: ‚ÄúClick polygon, then click a vertex, then follow prompts.‚Äù

Left-click anywhere inside a polygon. A message appears: ‚ÄúPolygon selected. Now click a vertex of this polygon.‚Äù Shows the lengths of all sides of the polygon If nothing happens: Ensure you're clicking on a polygon from an editable layer. Make sure the layer is in editing mode (pencil icon enabled). Zoom in to the polygon and left-click inside its boundary to select it.
Hover near the polygon‚Äôs edge; a green cross appears on a vertex. Click that highlighted vertex. If valid, a pop-up dialog appears to select the operation and distance/length.

You‚Äôll see two options: Move Vertex by Distance Move the selected vertex a certain distance in a direction you will choose on the map. Set Polygon Side Length Resize one side of the polygon to a specific length, keeping one vertex fixed. Enter a length in map units and press OK. warning ‚ö†Ô∏è Distance must not be zero. Side length must be positive.

A message appears: ‚ÄúClick to set move direction‚Äù or ‚ÄúClick to select side direction‚Äù Move your mouse to the desired direction. A blue preview line shows your adjustment. Click once to confirm the direction.
A confirmation dialog appears, showing: Distance and angle (for vertex move), or Old vs. new length (for side adjustment) Click Yes to apply the change, or No to cancel.
You can now start a new operation from Step 2. Or right-click anywhere on the map to reset the tool. A message appears: ‚ÄúReady. Right-click to reset, or left-click to start new operation.‚Äù

Message Meaning / Suggestion "No polygon found" You didn‚Äôt click inside a valid polygon. Try again. "Layer Not Editable" Enable edit mode for that layer (click the pencil icon). "No vertex found" You clicked too far from a vertex. Zoom in and try again. "Invalid side length" Selected side is too short or undefined. Pick another vertex.

Zoom in close for better accuracy when selecting vertices or directions. The green dot shows the selected vertex. The orange X shows your direction click. The preview lines help visualize before confirming.
Just select any other QGIS tool or press the Escape key/ Right click

The Svamitva PPM Tool is a QGIS Processing Algorithm that automates the generation of parcel-wise Property Parcel Maps. It uses plot and built-up shapefiles to generate map-ready outputs with symbology, labels, and atlas setup.
To avoid errors and ensure smooth tool operation, complete the following setup steps:
Your QGIS project must be saved (.qgz) before running the tool. All output files will be created relative to the saved project folder.
Both plot and built-up shapefiles must use the same CRS.
The plot shapefile must contain: A unique parcel ID field Area in square yards and square meters fields The built-up shapefile should: Contain polygons that lie within the plot boundaries
Plot and Built-up layers must be different. Using the same layer for both inputs will cause errors.
documents.s: ‚úÖ 4. Do Not Use the Same Layer for Plot and Built-up

documents.t: Parameter Description Example Choose Plot Area Shapefile Polygon layer with land parcels. plot_area.shp Property Parcel Number Field Field used to identify each parcel. prop_id Plot Area in Square Yards Field Area field in square yards. AREA_SQYRD Plot Area in Square Metres Field Area field in square meters. SHAPE_Area Choose Built-up (Plinth) Area Shapefile Built-up polygon layer inside plots. builtup.shp District Name (English) Choose your district. Srikakulam Mandal Name Name of the Mandal. Tekkali Grama Panchayat Name Name of the Panchayat. Anandapuram Grama Panchayat Code Panchayat code. 123456 Village LGD Code Village code (LGD). 567890
Follow these steps to successfully use the Svamitva PPM Generator:
Ensure your plot area shapefile and built-up area shapefile are ready. Both layers must use the same CRS as your QGIS project. Your QGIS project must be saved before running the tool.

In QGIS, go to: Processing ‚ñ∂ Toolbox ‚ñ∂ Gruhanaksha ‚ñ∂ PPM Generation Double-click the tool to launch the input form. or Click on the Icon in the Toolbar or From Plugin Menu: Plugins ‚ñ∂ Gruhanaksha ‚ñ∂ PPM Generation
Select your plot and built-up shapefiles. Choose the correct fields for Property ID, Area in Yards, and Area in Meters. Fill in district, mandal, panchayat, and village code details.

Click Run. The tool will: Validate inputs and CRS Add calculated fields (Ref_Col, Length, Area) Create boundary/exploded lines and vertices Save new layers to the project directory Apply styles from QML files Label the parcels Load a print-ready A4 Atlas template
You will see new layers in the Layers Panel: Plot_ExplodeLines, Builtup_ExplodeLines, Plot_Shapefile, Builtup_Shapefile, Plot_Vertices etc. Check for labels and colors applied automatically.
Go to Project ‚ñ∂ Layout Manager Open A4_PPM_TEMPLATE Click Atlas ‚ñ∂ Preview Atlas Use Atlas ‚ñ∂ Export as PDF or Print

Output File Description Plot_Boundary.shp Boundary of plot areas Plot_Shapefile.shp Plot area shapefile Builtup_Shapefile.shp Intersected built-up shapefile Plot_ExplodeLines.shp Exploded lines with length Builtup_ExplodeLines.shp Built-up exploded lines Plot_Vertices.shp All vertices of plot polygons Builtup_Boundary.shp Boundary of built-up A4_PPM_TEMPLATE Print layout ready for Atlas export
All output layers are saved inside the same folder where your .qgz project file is saved. If your project is not saved, the tool will raise an error.

Error Solution CRS Mismatch Ensure both layers and project have same CRS (e.g., EPSG:32645) Same Layer for Plot and Built-up Use two different shapefiles Missing Style File Check if assets_folder contains all .qml and .qpt files Unsaved Project Save the QGIS project before running the tool

Use clean and properly named fields in your input layers. Don't rename files to reserved names like Plot_ExplodeLines, Builtup_ExplodeLines, Plot_Shapefile, Builtup_Shapefile, Plot_Vertices. Save the QGIS project and keep it organized before starting. You can customize .qml and .qpt styles to match your district‚Äôs format.
If you encounter issues: Recheck your inputs and field names. Ensure all style/template files exist.

The Tool Panel is a floating window inside QGIS that gives access to multiple custom tools, useful for working with land parcels, base lines, and plotting boundaries. It includes buttons for: DrawLine ‚Äì For drawing base lines and circles. Plotter ‚Äì For visualizing and plotting triangles, bisectors, and angle tools. Adjuster ‚Äì For adjusting polygon areas or shapes interactively.

Once the plugin is installed, the Tool Panel can be opened from: A toolbar button, or Automatically as a floating window when QGIS starts (depending on your setup). The panel appears with the title: ‚ÄúTool Panel‚Äù and includes three buttons grouped under the label ‚ÄúTools‚Äù.

Icon: Use this to: Open the Baseline Tool which allows drawing reference lines (base lines) for plotting and measurements. Steps: Click DrawLine. The baseline tool will open. Use it to draw a line between two known points.

Icon: Use this to: Open the Combined Plotter Tool, which supports triangle plotting, angle bisectors, and more. Requirements: You must select one line feature from a line layer. What it shows: Displays the Start Point (green) and End Point (red) on the selected line. Opens a visual tool for plotting geometry based on those points.
Icon: Use this to: Open the Polygon Adjuster Tool, which helps resize or reshape polygon areas. Example: Increase the area of a plot while maintaining its general shape.

The Plotter and Adjuster tools use data from the currently selected feature(s) in your active QGIS layer. If you haven‚Äôt selected anything, or if the layer type is wrong (e.g., points instead of lines), you‚Äôll see a helpful error message.

When you use the Plotter Tool, it creates a point layer named ‚ÄúStart and End Points‚Äù: The Start Point is shown in green. The End Point is shown in red. You can see this layer in the Layers Panel, and it updates every time you select a new line and reopen the plotter.

Always make sure you select the correct feature before using a tool. Only one feature should be selected when using the Plotter Tool. You can clear or delete the ‚ÄúStart and End Points‚Äù layer if not needed later.

Problem What to Do Nothing happens when I click a button Make sure a valid layer and feature is selected. Error message appears Read the message carefully ‚Äì it tells you what‚Äôs missing (e.g., no line selected). Start/End points are not shown Check if the ‚ÄúStart and End Points‚Äù layer is added and visible.
Save the Project for Bhukamatha to work as intended (as Bhukamatha is dependent on the project sources) To save the project use shortcut Ctrl+S or use the save icon in the toolbar
Proper Zone selection for the project and Layers is important and must be done
